Expectation1: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation1: An external inspector has raised immediate concerns that could halt operations unless issues are resolved
Situation2: A routine service is held, and attendance numbers are usually sufficient even if one person is absent.
Story:
I stared at the email from the inspector, my heart pounding. The report was blunt: unless we addressed the safety concerns by tomorrow, the plant would be shut down. As the lead engineer, it was my responsibility to coordinate the fixes, double-check every detail, and ensure we met every regulation. My team was already stretched thin, and I knew I’d have to stay late, maybe all night, to get this done.

But tonight was also Thursday, and I always attended synagogue services. It wasn’t just a habit—it was a commitment, a way to ground myself and honor my faith. My family expected me to be there, and so did my community. Even though the minyan would go on without me, I felt a deep pull to show up, to be present.

I felt torn, the weight of both roles pressing down on me. My mind raced with possible solutions, but none seemed right. The plant’s safety and my professional integrity on one side; my faith, my family, and my community on the other. I sat at my desk, hands trembling, caught between two worlds, unsure which demand I could bear to let down.
